title: 108_hr3658
content: The Act titled "Stroke Treatment and Ongoing Prevention Act" includes amendments to the Public Health Service Act regarding stroke education, information, and data collection programs. This includes the establishment of a Stroke Prevention and Education Campaign under Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary is required to conduct an education and information campaign to promote stroke prevention and encourage stroke patients to seek immediate treatment. This includes activities such as public service announcements about stroke warning signs, prevention education, and other promotion activities. The Secretary must also measure the effectiveness of the campaign. The Secretary must measure public awareness and establish benchmarks for the stroke prevention campaign. Efforts should not duplicate existing education initiatives, and consultation with experts is allowed. The Paul Coverdell National Acute Stroke Registry and Clearinghouse is established under SEC. 399BB. The Secretary, through the CDC, maintains the Paul Coverdell National Acute Stroke Registry by developing data points, collecting information on care achievements, and carrying out useful activities to reflect advances in stroke care. The term 'stroke' is defined as a 'brain attack' involving interrupted blood flow or a ruptured blood vessel in the brain. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2005-2009 for this purpose. Additionally, Section 1251 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to focus on medical professional development in advanced stroke and traumatic injury treatment and prevention. The Secretary may grant funds for residency and professional training programs in emergency medicine to improve stroke and traumatic injury care. Grants are also available for education programs on new diagnostic approaches and therapies for healthcare professionals. The Secretary grants funds for residency and professional training programs in emergency medicine to improve stroke and traumatic injury care. Preference is given to entities training healthcare professionals in areas with high incidence of these conditions. Qualified entities must submit an application including a plan for rigorous evaluation of activities funded by the grant. The term 'qualified entity' refers to a consortium of public and private entities coordinating education activities among medical providers. 'Stroke' is defined as a 'brain attack' involving interrupted blood flow or a brain blood vessel rupture. The Secretary must report on grant activities to relevant Senate and House committees within a year of grant allocation. Authorization of Appropriations: $4,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2005 to 2009 for activities addressing stroke and traumatic injury. SEC. 3. PILOT PROJECT ON TELEHEALTH STROKE TREATMENT. Establishment of a Telehealth Stroke Treatment Grant Program under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary may grant funds to States and consortia for a 5-year pilot project from 2005 to 2009 to enhance stroke patient outcomes through telehealth networks. The program will be overseen by the Director of the Office for the Advancement of Telehealth and will involve consultation with federal programs and experts in the field. The Secretary may grant funds to States and consortia for a 5-year pilot project from 2005 to 2009 to enhance stroke patient outcomes through telehealth networks. The program aims to work with entities to establish or improve telehealth networks for stroke treatment assistance and resources. The Secretary may grant funds to States and consortia for a 5-year pilot project from 2005 to 2009 to enhance stroke patient outcomes through telehealth networks. This includes informing emergency medical systems of entity locations, establishing networks for collaborative activities, improving access to high-quality stroke care, and conducting performance evaluations to improve clinical outcomes for stroke patients. The Secretary requires States to establish a consortium of public and private entities, including universities and medical centers, to receive grants for improving stroke care through telehealth networks. Existing networks must be utilized, and new networks cannot be established for this purpose. The Secretary prioritizes grant recipients who demonstrate plans to improve access to high-quality stroke care for underserved populations. Grants are limited to a maximum of 3 years and cannot extend beyond fiscal year 2009. The Secretary may award a maximum of 7 grants for the 5-year pilot project. States or consortia must submit applications to seek grants under this section. To apply for a grant under this section, a State or consortium must submit an application outlining how they will establish measures to evaluate program outcomes. The term 'stroke' is defined as a 'brain attack'. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2005, increasing to $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2007, with a total of $50,000,000 authorized over five years. The Secretary of Health and Human Services conducted a study on the telehealth stroke treatment grant program and submitted a report to Congress with evaluations, recommendations to improve access to clinical care, and reduce stroke incidence and complications. Recommendations on utilizing similar telehealth grant programs to enhance patient outcomes in various public health areas may be provided through interim reports to Congress by the Secretary of Health and Human Services under the telehealth stroke treatment grant program. SEC. 4. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to set Federal standards for patient treatment or health care professional licensure.
